Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2008 05:30PM mary6204 wrote: Congratulations Marionleah, we need many more posts like yours.  I pray your health continues for many, many years.  It gives us all hope. I'm only 3 months past chemo, but I'm feeling great and fairly optomistic.  Good luck and God Bless, Mary
Posts.Title: 5 years this week! marianleah Nanda

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 05:54PM mary6204 wrote: Oh Laniney, I'm so sorry.  I remember only too well the day I got that phone call.  I was numb as well and never cried for several hours.  Stages is mostly about whether it's spread.  My cancer was stage one which was a .7 tumor that was an aggressive type, so it was grade 3.  The worst part is waiting for the results after scans and such.  I was relieved it hadn't spread, but being that it was grade 3 I went through chemo from the end of March this year til the beginning of July.  It wasn't fun, but I survived.  This is the place to come to for support and questions.  Ev eryone here helped me so much and we're all  here for you as well.  Ask all the questions you need.  I'll say a prayer for you tonight.  Mary
Posts.Title: Received my diagnois tonight..IDC Lainey64 Lainey64

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2008 04:53AM mary6204 wrote: Dear Fly, I'm not one to give out much information as I am pretty new to this as well.  I am HER+ and I was supposed to be getting my first treatment that includes Herceptin in a couple of hours, but I got the flu Sunday night and was still yucky yesterday morning.  I called the oncologist and they rescheduled me for Thursday, yea two more days of hair!!!! The only thing I'm actually actually answering about your questions is regarding the mascetomy because my Mom had one.  She had breast cancer at age 80. Since it was hormone receptive she had radation and took Tamoxifen.  Before the 5 years were over, she had a reoccurance and had a masectomy.  It had already spread and she died less than two years later.  Although I am dreading chemo, for me it's the only answer.  The good news is my Mom was 84 yrs old when she had her breast removed.  Three days after surgery she was on a chair taking down pictures because they were moving.  She had almost no down time.  From what I've talked to with other people, I think a lot of it is more mental than anything else.  Boob's meant nothing to my Mom so she got over it very quickly. especially for her age.  Everyone is different, but I wish you luck with your situation.  I am grateful that my surgeon did not feel a mascetomy would do me any good.  I've had 3 minor surgeries in the past 6 weeks, including having the port installed. Frankly, I'm tired of having to give up my coffee in the mornings.  Good luck and God Bless you, Mary
Posts.Title: confused about HER2+ and ER+ flyrzfan jeanette51

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2008 06:45PM mary6204 wrote: I had 6 treatments of TCH.  I had a slight problem with low platelets after just one tx.  My blood count didn't go as low as most women I know.  I had horrible, horrible diarrhea and nausea for 5 to 9 days with each tx, until we found that what helped my nausea was to stay on the steriods longer.  I had absolutely NO neurapathy or pain of any kind.  It's been almost 4 months since my treatments ended, except for the Herceptin,and I feel fabulous.  I never got that tired, except when I had my sick days.  I went to the gym after the nausea lifted.  I feel great and completely full of energy.  I felt that reading a lot of info from other woman that the ones that go through TCH, Taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin have it a little easier.  Plus I get zero s/e from Herceptin. Life is pretty good again.  I hope this helps, but I have to say I know nothing about Doxil.  Good Luck and God Bless, Mary
Posts.Title: CARBOPLATIN IS TOUGH ON WHAT SIDE EFFECTS? lida TripleNeg

Posts.Content: May 22, 2008 11:03AM mary6204 wrote: Abrede, I know how scary it can all be.  I had a large lump I found 8 years ago, was never told what the size was.  I had a lumpectomy and it ended up being benign.  Then this January a very small lump .7 cent showed up on a routine mammagram and it was indeed cancer.  I then had more tissue tested as well as a sentinel node biopsy and found it had not spread at all.  As thankful as I was, it turned out to be an aggressive type of cancer and I am now half way through chemo so that it doesn't reoccur.  I have days when I'm really sick, but fortunely most of the time, like now, I feel really good and like myself (except for this rug on my head).  Hopefully yours will turn out like my first time.  They did tell me that as large as the lump was the first time, it probably wasn't cancer because with routine mammagrams, it wouldn't have grown to that size since my last test, and they were right. God Bless and I hope it all works out for you.  This site helps me a lot. Please let us know what your results are.  Good luck, Mary
Posts.Title: It's all happening so fast.. abrede Looneymom

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 08:29AM mary6204 wrote: My heart goes out to you and your family.  I lost my mom to BC October 10, 2005 which was her 63rd Wedding anniversary. God bless you through this difficult time. Mary
Posts.Title: My mom is an angel now EXAIMA omo

Posts.Content: May 31, 2008 07:19AM mary6204 wrote: I'm so sorry for what the two of you are going through, but this is the place to come.  I get great support and it's so helpful to talk to others with the same problems. When my journey started in January, I was a basket case.  The waiting is definitely the hardest part.  My 4th out of 6 chemo treatments was Wednesday.  It's not easy or fun, but it's better than all the waiting.  I'm so looking forward to getting past this.  Hopefully, your tests will come back okay.  I had abnomal bleeding and cramping several years ago and it ended up being nothing serious.  I also had a lump removed 8 years ago that ended up being benign, so don't give up hope.  God Bless you both and keep us informed, Mary
Posts.Title: Cancer jschmitt jschmitt

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2008 12:26AM mary6204 wrote: I know of people who do chemo and their scores are in the teens.  I'm so glad I did it because I know I did everything I could to keep it from coming back.  The rest is in God's hands. For me, TCH made me really sick anywhere from 5 to 9 days, but the rest of the 3weeks in between tx's I felt great, never got tired,kept up with the gym.  I'm glad it's over, but it was do-able.  Losing the hair was perhaps the hardest part, but it's coming in very, very thick and curly.  My last tx was 7/9/08.  Good luck and God bless, we're here for you.  Mary

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2010 12:21AM mary6204 wrote: Hi Mouse, just thought I'd throw in my 2 cents worth.  I had 6 TCH treatments starting 3/08.  Taxotere made me sick starting the 4th day and with each treatment it was longer.  My last one I was sick for 8 days,  I was told that was quite unusual.  I had no other side effects (except for the hairloss of course)  Once I was on Herceptin alone, absolutely nothing.  No edema, no nerve problems.  It was a piece of cake.  Last Herceptin was last March and I feel great, my heart is fine and I have a beautiful head of hair.  My only problem is I freak out before mammagrams.  My next one is tomorrow and I am stressed to the max.  I guess that will never end.  Good luck and God bless, it does get better.  Mary

Posts.Content: mary6204 wrote: This morning I get my results from my echocardiagram to determine whether I can continue with herceptin.  I've had 5 treatments so far.  My heart pounds every now and then and it really scares me.  I would prefer not to delay the treatment, but I'm mostly concerned with what it could do to my heart.  If anyone has had to delay their herceptin treatments I'd love to know.  How long of a break does it take to get it back to normal?  Has anyone had to stop completely?  Any information would be appreciated.  My last chemo is suppose to be this morning and it would include herceptin No. 6.  God Bless, Mary Dx 2/7/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 12:19PM mary6204 wrote: Sounds like most of us are doing well right now.  My nausea is finally gone.  Otter, that list was impressive.  Noelle, I live with and take care of my 90 yrs old Dad so I can appreciate what you went through with your mom.  It's not easy; and going through chemo at he same time is hard.  Good luck to everyone this week; tonights the day I have my daughter shave my head.  Should have done it last week, don't know why I was holding on.  But right now I am so sick of hair, hair, hair.  Between me and my cat it's ridiculous in my computer room.  Hair's flying everywhere; maybe I should shave her too.  Mary

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 07:50PM mary6204 wrote: I didn't realize herceptin could be given seperately?  I'm having my head shaved today.  I started losing my hair big time 12 days ago and I still have a lot left.  I just can't stand it anymore.  There is hair everywhere.  My husband cut it to within an inch a couple of days ago, but it's still driving me crazy. I've been wearing a sleep cap to keep hair off my pillow cause Im tired of it in my mouth during the night.  The other night I put it on a realized it was inside-out, so I took if off and couldn't even put it back on because it was so covered in hair.  Had to get out the lint brush at 11pm.  I thought I was doing myself a favor by just letting it fall out naturally.  NOT!!!  I think I will be so happy to have it gone.  My daughters doing it at 4:30 pm; less than 2 hours of hair left and then I will be bald like I should have been last week.  Mary

Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2008 11:35PM mary6204 wrote: I am sorry your so worried.  It's very possible that it's nothing to worry about; but it's not a chance you can take.  You need to see a doctor and find out what's going on.  The most important thing about breast cancer is early detection.  I know someone who did indeed have breast cancer at the exact age you are. She went through chemo and is now a 31 year survivor.  But if you choose to ignore it you might not be so lucky.  It's not worth the risk.  Hopefully it's not cancer again, but only a doctor can determine it, so please go see one.  Good luck and God bless, Mary
Posts.Title: Should i be worried chels chels

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 05:35PM mary6204 wrote: Roberta, I am also on a 6 X every 3 week regimen although it's TCH.  My doctor assured me that working out would help a lot.  I made it to the gym twice the week of my first two treatments.  The day before and the day after.  My 2nd treatment was yesterday and I felt great this morning, so I got in an excellent workout.  I know tomorrow my side effects will start,  but I really hope to go for the next 2 weeks.  I wish you good luck, working out really, really helps.  Mary

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 04:54PM mary6204 wrote: Yuck, yuck, yuck is how I feel today.  I can hardly stay awake, but I think I'll be better tomorrow. Lauren, I'm so glad you have your son's hugs.  Just imagine how much all this will strengthen your relationship.  He's going to mature a little faster by being there for Mom and it's great to have that special tie. Kalyla, my scalp was painful yesterday morning and Paul Mitchell's Tea Tree Oil conditioner took the soreness away. cinlee, my hair started falling out day 16, today is day 23 for me, or 3 days after second treatment.  I still have a lot left, but it's a big mess of fuzz.  Still can't get motivated to shave it though.  I wrapped it in a mesh bag and have on a scarf.  Yesterday I wore my wig all day, but today, too icky to care. Cheer's to all of you that can work through this.  I think it's wonderful.  Right now I just can't wait to go to bed and hopefully feel more energetic tomorrow.  Hope everyone has a good evening.  Our regular Friday evening dinner's with family and a couple of beers are out of the question for me tonight. Mary

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2008 06:48PM mary6204 wrote: Kristyann, I have had 2 treatments of TCH. My hair was fully entact at day 14, then on day 15 I noticed the first few strands.  My second treatment was 19 days after the first (instead of 21, cause I had the flu) I went to it with still enough hair to look decent.  I started wearing scarves and my wig the next day and had it shaved yesterday which would have been day 28.  Really should have done it a few days earlier, but even yesterday I still didn't have a single balding spot, but I couldn't stand the hair in my food, on my pillow or in the scarves I was wearing.  I'd say you have a few "good hair" days left, enjoy them.  Good luck, Mary

Posts.Content: mary6204 wrote: There has got to be some medicine out there that will work for me.  Compazine did nothing, Zofran helps for one day.  Today I took Tigan and it's helping just a tiny bit.  I don't want to stay in bed dizzy for 4 days, but it's odd because I don't get hit with it til day 5 through 8.  By that time all the steriods and emend which I took Day 1 through 3 has worn off.   It doesn't sound like many woman have this problem so late into the cycle, but if there's something anyone could suggest I try, I would really appreciate it.  I'm so dizzy I just can't take it anymore. Posts.Title: anti-nausea drugs mary6204 leaf

Posts.Content: May 31, 2008 03:42PM mary6204 wrote: Thanks again for all the advice, I had my 4th treatment Wednesday and the onc wanted to stay on top of it by having me go to the hospital this morning for an IV.  When I got there I had nausea and dizziness and it was even worse when I left.  I went home and straight to bed and the nausea just kept flushing over me in waves which kept me from sleeping even though I'm exhausted.  I finally got up and decided to force feed myself a lite lunch, or actually my husband fixed it,  and I then took my first Ativan.  They gave it to me at the end of the nausea for tx #3 so I didn't need it then.  It's so weird, it's like it's lifted the feelings from my body and I don't feel too bad right now.  I never thought I would need something like this, but it's true I do get panicy when I have the nausea and I think it has a lot to do with the things I can't take care of when I'm sick.  Having my 90 yr old Dad live with us is the hardest by far.  I have no privacy, always have to do things for him and worry about what he's going to do next.  He's always in the living room watching Westerns which drives me crazy, thank heavens for my den.  I prayed that I wouldn't have to go through chemo as long as he was with us, but that was one prayer that wasn't answered. Oh well, if I can get relief from a drug like this I'll take it.  I just hope it keeps helping and I can get through this.  I know I'm one of the lucky ones, but sometimes it's hard to realize it.  Thanks again for the advice gals, Mary
Posts.Title: anti-nausea drugs mary6204 leaf

Posts.Content: May 11, 2008 03:56PM mary6204 wrote: Thanks Nancy, that's interesting that you mention ears.  I told my husband the other day that my ear is clogged; I never thought it could be related.  Otherwise I called the pharmacist and he told me not to take the emend until the first day I generally get the nausea, which is day 4 or 5.  Too late for this treatment, but I'll wait until the next one and do it right.  I am feeling a little better, and I'm going to try to eat some dinner.  All I've had otherwise for the last 2 days is Coke.  I'll never want to drink pop again.  Hope everyone's having a good Mother's Day.  Mary
Posts.Title: anti-nausea drugs mary6204 leaf

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2008 08:09PM mary6204 wrote: Good luck Tina, I had Taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin and sorry to say, I was really sick with each treatment.  I was fine until day 3 or 4 then the nausea hit me.  As hard as it was, I bounced back after all six treatments and I am fabulous now.  I am so glad it's over (last tx 7/9/08), but I'm so glad I did it.  Anything to keep this nasty disease from coming back is good.  You'll do fine and God bless you and your loved ones.  Mary

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 07:54PM mary6204 wrote: Lauren, I've bought a lot of stuff from headcovers.com it's a great place.  One thing I got yesterday is a gel band to wear around your head to take the pressure points off from wearing a wig.  I plan on trying it out soon.  I agree on the wig quality.  I have 2 right now, one is a cheap one and the other is a mono as well as hand tied.  They're more expensive, but I've heard its worth it.  Especially since I still get hot flashes and Michigan summers are so humid. Otter, there's a place called ultimatelooks.com  that also charges a 15% restock fee, however, the first exchange is free.  Don't know if that helps. I am feeling bad today, but I think I need to eat.  Nothing sounds good.  I'm going to suck it up, get dressed, try the pressure band with my wig and go to dinner with my husband.  I hope it helps.  I'm out of Zofran, so I need to get that filled as well.  Mary
Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 07:42AM mary6204 wrote: I am on TCH and have had 2 treatments.   I get Aloxi in my IV and that along with the steriods I take last for a few days.  The first treatment I didn't get nausea until day 6, this past treatment it started day 5 and lasted through day 8.  I know a lot of woman have problems with zofran, but it works for me when the nausea starts.  It doesn't give me headaches like some and since I am battling with diahrrea, constipation doesn't seem to be a problem. Besides the Zofran, I just got a script for tigan but I haven't used it yet.  2 of the doctors in the group I see, 1 of the nurses as well as a pharmacist told me do not take the anti-nausea medicine until you need it.  They all have side effects as well and if you take it before it's needed sometimes it won't work when you do.  Compazine is known to cause a lock-jaw like symtom, but only if it builds up in your system.  However it didn't do anything for me. I actually do best on a home remedy that's not recommended so I won't say what it is. I've heard from women that swear by each individual drugs so it proves everyone is different.  Good luck, I think in the beginning it's a guessing game.  Some women don't get the nausea at all; must be nice!!!!  Mary
Posts.Title: ant-nausea drugs foe THC tomatojuice mary6204
